review.title: Cognitive Dynamic Systems: A Technical Review of Cognitive Radar
review.abstract: We start with the history of cognitive radar, where origins of the PAC, Fuster research on cognition and principals of cognition are provided. Fuster describes five cognitive functions: perception, memory, attention, language, and intelligence. We describe the Perception-Action Cyclec as it applies to cognitive radar, and then discuss long-term memory, memory storage, memory retrieval and working memory. A comparison between memory in human cognition and cognitive radar is given as well. Attention is another function described by Fuster, and we have given the comparison of attention in human cognition and cognitive radar. We talk about the four functional blocks from the PAC: Bayesian filter, feedback information, dynamic programming and state-space model for the radar environment. Then, to show that the PAC improves the tracking accuracy of Cognitive Radar over Traditional Active Radar, we have provided simulation results. In the simulation, three nonlinear filters: Cubature Kalman Filter, Unscented Kalman Filter and Extended Kalman Filter are compared. Based on the results, radars implemented with CKF perform better than the radars implemented with UKF or radars implemented with EKF. Further, radar with EKF has the worst accuracy and has the biggest computation load because of derivation and evaluation of Jacobian matrices. We suggest using the concept of risk management to better control parameters and improve performance in cognitive radar. We believe, spectrum sensing can be seen as a potential interest to be used in cognitive radar and we propose a new approach Probabilistic ICA which will presumably reduce noise based on estimation error in cognitive radar. Parallel computing is a concept based on divide and conquers mechanism, and we suggest using the parallel computing approach in cognitive radar by doing complicated calculations or tasks to reduce processing time.

sections.text: The human cognitive cycle refers to high-level brain functions that deal with the understanding of information, its processing and the retention of knowledge. Cognition focuses in particular on the logical or analytical aspects as opposed to the emotional. sections.heading: B. Cognitive Functions
sections.text: In his book, CORTEX AND MIND: UNIFYING COGNITION, Fuster describes five cognitive functions: perception, memory, attention, language and intelligence. Perception refers to the understanding of the world or the environment around it. It goes beyond simple sensory input and includes functions of memory and attention. In neurobiological terms, perception involves the activation of cognits or cortical networks that make up memories. Memory deals with the ability to retain information about oneself and the environment. This information includes both conscious and unconscious knowledge, the mental traces of experience, acquired facts and relationships between facts. [1] Memory formation (sometimes called memory encoding) involves the formation of cortical networks and the strengthening of synapses that form these networks to create associations in which memories can be retrieved.

sections.heading: C. Cognitive Dynamic systems
sections.text: The first papers on cognitive dynamic systems in 2005 and 2006 did not refer to Fuster, the perceptual action cycle or any of the principles of cognition. However, cognitive radar was specifically inspired by the echolocation of bats, and it is not difficult to see how the perceptual action cycle is applied directly to bats? Ability to navigate their environment and locate food based on the sounds they emit. Subsequent papers on cognitive dynamic systems have adopted ideas from Fuster's work. Due to the similarity of the structure between cognitive radar and human cognition, in particular the overall structure of the perceptive action cycle, cognitive radar is well positioned to benefit from Fuster's work on the functions of cognition.

sections.heading: A. Risk Management and Cognitive Radar
sections.text: Considering cognitive radar as a complicated system, there are many parameters and factors that need to be controlled in order to improve system performance and minimize any risks that might appear to be errors. In such a case, the concept of risk management from an economic point of view can be helpful in extracting risk factors from our system and solving arithmetic problems such as noise reduction. Risk management is an organized method for identifying and measuring risks and for selecting, developing and implementing options for managing risks [12]. 13 Explains the risk hierarchy in a given system. Risk planning is the continuous development of an organized, comprehensive approach to torisk management. The initial planning includes: defining a strategy; defining objectives and goals; planning, managing and monitoring activities; identifying resources, tasks and responsibilities; organizing and training IPT members in risk management; establishing a method for tracking risks and documenting them continuously; and establishing a method for determining and distributing risks.

sections.heading: D. Parallel computing and processing
sections.text: Parallel computing is a concept in computation in which many calculations are performed simultaneously, and the main concept is to divide large problems into smaller ones that can be solved simultaneously. There are several different forms of parallel computation such as bit level, command level, data and task parallelism [1]. As is well known, in cognitive dynamic systems we face difficulties such as: big data processing; information overload and overflow; limited resources; and resource allocation. In practice, parallel computing and processing are of potential interest in solving the above problems computationally. Although parallel computing seems to make the system more complex and expensive, the currently available Universal Graphics Processing Unit (GPGPU) can be used. Since cognitive radar systems include real-time systems and online tracking, GPGPU can be used as part of the system to perform many tasks within the perception and action cycle.

sections.heading: V. REPORT SUMMARY
sections.text: We have developed and successfully tested our new PySpark-based pipeline on a single node to analyze functional MRI data to extract brain networks, which improved processing time about four times faster than previous work with consistent accuracy. In addition, ease of use, in-memory data processing and storage of results in different data structures are some of the key features of this pipeline. In addition, this pipeline can easily be expanded to multiple nodes and high-performance computing cycles to perform massive data analysis on large data sets, which will significantly improve processing time and performance of the pipeline more than a single node.

metadata.abstractText: In this report we discuss the mechanisms of cognitive radar. This report is organized as follows: We start with the history of cognitive radar, where origins of the PAC, Fuster?s research on cognition and principals of cognition are provided. Fuster describes five cognitive functions: perception, memory, attention, language, and intelligence. We describe the Perception-Action Cyclec (PAC) as it applies to cognitive radar, and then discuss long-term memory, memory storage, memory retrieval and working memory. A comparison between memory in human cognition and cognitive radar is given as well. Attention is another function described by Fuster, and we have given the comparison of attention in human cognition and cognitive radar. We talk about the four functional blocks from the PAC: Bayesian filter, feedback information, dynamic programming and state-space model for the radar environment. Then, to show that the PAC improves the tracking accuracy of Cognitive Radar over Traditional Active Radar, we have provided simulation results. In the simulation, three nonlinear filters: Cubature Kalman Filter (CKF), Unscented Kalman Filter (UKF) and Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) are compared. Based on the results, radars implemented with CKF perform better than the radars implemented with UKF or radars implemented with EKF. Further, radar with EKF has the worst accuracy and has the biggest computation load because of derivation and evaluation of Jacobian matrices. In addition, we suggest using the concept of risk management to better control parameters and improve performance in cognitive radar, especially in noise reduction. We believe, spectrum sensing can be seen as a potential interest to be used in cognitive radar and we propose a new approach Probabilistic Independent Component Analysis (PICA) which will presumably reduce noise based on estimation error in cognitive radar. Parallel computing is a concept based on divide and conquers mechanism, and in this report we suggest to use the parallel computing approach in cognitive radar by doing complicated calculations or tasks to reduce processing time, increase speed of system and higher precision. With the increased use of parallel computing in other fields of engineering, General-purpose computing on graphics processing units (GPGPU) would be the best way to implement parallel computing in cognitive radar.
